page.title: 19ECOLOGY OF THE REGION
page.content: THE AREA WAS ONCE HEAVILY WOODED AND A WIDE VARIETY OG TREES ARE STILL TO BE FOUND, BOTH INDIGENOUS AND INTRODUCED. MUCH OF THE AREA IS LOW-LYING, WITH AREAS OF WET, PEATY LAND AND SALT MARSHES BOARDERING THE EAST OF THE REGION. THERE IS A PROFUSION OF WILD FLOWERS TO BE FOUND IN ENVIRONMENTS RANGING FROM HEATHLAND TO WOODLAND. ALTHOUGH MANY OF THE HEDGES HAVE BEEN REMOVED TO CREATE LARGER FIELDS, THERE ARE STILL MANY ROADSIDE VERGES WHICH OFFER A SUPER HABITAT FOR WILD FLOWERS AND CREATURES. RABBITS, HARES, FOXES, DEER, AND ALL COMMON WILD BIRDS ARE TO BE FOUND IN THE REGION. KESTRELS ARE PARTICULARLY COMMON. THE CLIMATE OF THE REGION IS GREATLY INFLUENCED BY ITS PROXIMITY TO THE EAST COAST AND COLD WINDS ARE A PARTICULAR FEATURE.
